batchName: REG Medium Application - Tax & Law Scenarios

questions.question: A teacher spends $400 on classroom supplies. She may deduct as an above-the-line adjustment:
questions.explanation: The educator expense deduction allows eligible teachers to deduct up to $300 (as adjusted for inflation) for unreimbursed classroom expenses as an above-the-line deduction. The excess may be deductible as a miscellaneous itemized deduction subject to limitations.
questions.tip: Educator expense = above-the-line up to the limit. Check current limit annually—it adjusts for inflation.

questions.question: A married couple filing jointly has modified AGI of $60,000 and Social Security benefits of $20,000. What is the maximum percentage of benefits that may be taxable?
questions.explanation: Social Security benefits are taxed based on provisional income (MAGI + 50% of benefits). At higher income levels, up to 85% of benefits can be taxable. The maximum taxable amount is always 85%, never 100%.
questions.tip: Social Security taxation: 0%, 50%, or up to 85% based on provisional income. Never more than 85%.

questions.question: The Net Investment Income Tax (NIIT) of 3.8% applies to:

options.A: All investment income regardless of AGI
options.B: Investment income when MAGI exceeds threshold amounts

questions.explanation: The 3.8% NIIT applies to the lesser of net investment income OR the excess of MAGI over threshold ($200,000 single, $250,000 MFJ). It applies to interest, dividends, capital gains, rental income, and passive income.
questions.tip: NIIT = 3.8% on lesser of NII or MAGI over threshold. Not just capital gains—includes interest, dividends, passive income.

questions.question: A father sells stock to his daughter for $10,000. His basis is $15,000. What is the tax treatment?

options.B: Loss disallowed; daughter takes $10,000 basis
options.D: Loss deferred until daughter sells the stock

questions.explanation: Losses on sales between related parties (family members) are disallowed. The buyer takes the purchase price as basis. However, if the buyer later sells at a gain, the previously disallowed loss can offset that gain.
questions.tip: Related party loss = disallowed but may reduce buyer's future gain. Daughter's basis = $10,000 (cost).

questions.question: A taxpayer sells stock for a $3,000 loss on December 15 and buys substantially identical stock on January 5 of the next year. What is the result?

options.A: $3,000 loss allowed; new stock basis equals cost
options.B: Loss disallowed; new stock basis increased by disallowed loss
options.C: Loss allowed because purchase was in different tax year
options.D: Loss deferred to the year of subsequent sale

questions.explanation: The wash sale rule disallows losses when substantially identical stock is acquired within 30 days before or after the sale. The disallowed loss is added to the basis of the replacement stock.
questions.tip: Wash sale = 61-day window (30 before, sale date, 30 after). Loss added to new stock's basis.

questions.question: A business property destroyed by fire had a basis of $100,000. Insurance proceeds were $150,000. To defer all gain under Section 1033, the taxpayer must reinvest at least:
questions.explanation: To defer the entire gain in an involuntary conversion, the taxpayer must reinvest an amount equal to or greater than the proceeds received ($150,000). Reinvesting less results in gain recognized to the extent of the deficiency.
questions.tip: Section 1033: Reinvest full proceeds to defer all gain. Unlike 1031, you reinvest proceeds, not value.

questions.question: A taxpayer above the income threshold has QBI of $200,000 from a non-SSTB business with W-2 wages of $100,000 and no UBIA. The QBI deduction is limited to:
questions.explanation: Above the threshold, the QBI deduction is limited to the greater of: (a) 50% of W-2 wages, or (b) 25% of W-2 wages plus 2.5% of UBIA. Here: 50% × $100,000 = $50,000 is greater than $25,000 (25% × $100,000 + 0).
questions.tip: W-2 limitation: Greater of 50% wages OR (25% wages + 2.5% UBIA). Compare to 20% QBI.

questions.question: A corporation has taxable income of $500,000 before charitable contributions and a $75,000 charitable contribution. What is the current year deduction?
questions.explanation: Corporate charitable deductions are limited to 10% of taxable income computed without the charitable deduction, NOL carryback, or DRD. Limit = 10% × $500,000 = $50,000. The $25,000 excess carries forward 5 years.
questions.tip: C corp charitable limit = 10% of adjusted taxable income. Excess carries forward 5 years.

questions.question: A corporation owns 25% of another domestic corporation and receives $100,000 in dividends. The dividends received deduction is:
questions.explanation: DRD percentages: <20% ownership = 50% DRD, 20-79% ownership = 65% DRD, 80%+ ownership = 100% DRD. At 25% ownership, the 65% DRD applies: $100,000 × 65% = $65,000.
questions.tip: DRD tiers: <20% = 50%, 20-79% = 65%, 80%+ = 100%. Ownership determines the percentage.

questions.question: The personal holding company tax is designed to prevent:

options.A: Accumulation of earnings to avoid corporate tax
options.B: Using closely held corporations to shelter passive income from individual tax rates

questions.explanation: The PHC tax targets closely held corporations (5 or fewer individuals own >50% of stock) that primarily earn passive income (dividends, rents, royalties). It prevents deferral of passive income at lower corporate rates.
questions.tip: PHC tax: Closely held + passive income = penalty tax. Forces distribution of investment income.

questions.question: A C corporation with appreciated assets converts to S status. If these assets are sold within the recognition period, the S corporation may be subject to:

options.A: Corporate income tax on all gain
options.B: Built-in gains tax on pre-conversion appreciation
options.D: No corporate-level tax because it's an S corporation

questions.explanation: The built-in gains tax applies to S corporations that were formerly C corporations. If assets with built-in gain at conversion are sold within the recognition period (5 years), a corporate-level tax applies on the pre-conversion gain.
questions.tip: BIG tax = corporate tax on C corp appreciation sold within 5 years of S election. Prevents C-to-S conversion abuse.

questions.question: An S corporation with accumulated E&P from C years makes a distribution. The distribution is first applied to:

options.B: AAA, then accumulated E&P

questions.explanation: S corporation distributions are applied in order: (1) AAA (tax-free return of previously taxed income), (2) Accumulated E&P (taxable dividend), (3) Stock basis (tax-free return of capital), (4) Excess (capital gain).
questions.tip: S corp distribution order: AAA → AE&P → Basis → Gain. AAA represents S corp earnings already taxed to shareholders.

questions.question: A partner receives a guaranteed payment of $50,000 for services. This amount is:

options.A: Deductible by the partnership and ordinary income to the partner
options.B: Not deductible by the partnership but ordinary income to the partner
options.C: Deductible by the partnership and capital gain to the partner

questions.explanation: Guaranteed payments are deductible by the partnership in computing ordinary income and are ordinary income to the receiving partner. They're similar to salary—deductible expense to payer, ordinary income to recipient.
questions.tip: Guaranteed payments = like salary. Deductible to partnership, ordinary income to partner, subject to SE tax.

questions.question: A partner sells their partnership interest when the partnership owns unrealized receivables and appreciated inventory. Gain attributable to these 'hot assets' is:

options.A: Capital gain because it's a sale of partnership interest
options.B: Ordinary income under Section 751
options.D: Subject to depreciation recapture rules only

questions.explanation: Section 751 'hot assets' (unrealized receivables and inventory) convert what would otherwise be capital gain into ordinary income. This prevents converting ordinary income assets into capital gain through entity sale.
questions.tip: Hot assets (751): Unrealized receivables + inventory. Gain = ordinary income, not capital gain.

questions.question: A trust that may accumulate income, make charitable contributions, or distribute corpus is classified as:

options.B: Complex trust

questions.explanation: A complex trust is any trust that is not a simple trust. Simple trusts must distribute all income currently, cannot make charitable contributions from trust income, and cannot distribute principal. Complex trusts can do any of these.
questions.tip: Simple trust = must distribute all income, no charity, no principal distribution. Anything else = complex.

questions.question: In a grantor trust, the trust income is taxed to:

options.A: The trust at trust tax rates
options.B: The beneficiaries based on distributions
options.C: The grantor as if the trust didn't exist

questions.explanation: A grantor trust is ignored for income tax purposes. All income, deductions, and credits are reported on the grantor's personal return as if the trust assets were still owned directly by the grantor.
questions.tip: Grantor trust = tax transparent. Grantor taxed on all income. Trust is disregarded for income tax.

questions.question: A decedent owned a life insurance policy on her own life, payable to her children. The policy's face value is included in her gross estate because:

options.B: The decedent had incidents of ownership at death
options.C: Life insurance is always included in the gross estate

questions.explanation: Life insurance proceeds are included in the gross estate if the decedent had 'incidents of ownership' (the right to change beneficiaries, borrow against policy, etc.) at death, or if proceeds are payable to the estate.
questions.tip: Life insurance in estate if: (1) payable to estate, OR (2) decedent had incidents of ownership. Transfer policy to avoid inclusion.

questions.question: A married taxpayer makes a $50,000 gift to a non-spouse. If the spouse consents to gift splitting, each spouse is treated as giving:
questions.explanation: Gift splitting allows a married couple to treat a gift made by one spouse as made half by each. The $50,000 gift is split: $25,000 attributed to each spouse. Each can then apply their annual exclusion to their portion.
questions.tip: Gift splitting = divide gift between spouses. Double the exclusion available. Requires spouse consent.

questions.question: The accuracy-related penalty for a substantial understatement of income tax is:

options.B: 20% of the underpayment

questions.explanation: The accuracy-related penalty is 20% of the underpayment for: (1) negligence, (2) substantial understatement (>$5,000 or 10% of correct tax), (3) substantial valuation misstatement, or (4) transaction lacking economic substance.
questions.tip: Accuracy penalty = 20%. Fraud penalty = 75%. Substantial understatement = >$5,000 or 10% of tax.

questions.question: In a civil tax case, the burden of proof generally lies with:

options.B: The taxpayer to substantiate deductions and income
options.C: The court to determine correct tax
options.D: The preparer who signed the return

questions.explanation: Taxpayers generally bear the burden of proof to substantiate items on their returns. The burden can shift to the IRS if the taxpayer maintains adequate records, cooperates, and meets credibility requirements under IRC Section 7491.
questions.tip: Taxpayer has burden of proof initially. Can shift to IRS with good records and cooperation.

questions.question: Which of the following would constitute valid consideration for a contract?

options.A: A promise to make a gift
options.B: A promise to forbear from exercising a legal right
options.C: Past consideration for services already performed
options.D: A promise to do what one is already legally obligated to do

questions.explanation: Valid consideration requires a bargained-for exchange of legal value. Forbearance (giving up a legal right) constitutes valid consideration. Gifts, past consideration, and pre-existing duties generally do not.
questions.tip: Consideration = legal detriment to promisee OR legal benefit to promisor. Must be bargained-for.

questions.question: A life insurance policy naming a spouse as beneficiary creates which type of third-party beneficiary?

options.A: Incidental beneficiary with no contract rights
options.B: Intended donee beneficiary with enforceable rights

questions.explanation: A donee beneficiary is an intended third-party beneficiary who receives the benefit as a gift (not to satisfy a debt). Life insurance beneficiaries are typically donee beneficiaries with enforceable contract rights.
questions.tip: Intended beneficiary = enforceable rights. Donee (gift) vs Creditor (debt payment). Incidental = no rights.

questions.question: When an agent acts for an undisclosed principal, who can be held liable on the contract?

options.B: Only the principal once disclosed
options.D: Neither until the contract is ratified

questions.explanation: When the principal is undisclosed, both the agent and principal can be held liable because the third party contracted with the agent personally. The agent remains liable even after the principal is disclosed.
questions.tip: Undisclosed principal: Agent personally liable. Principal also liable once discovered. Third party can choose.

questions.question: In a limited liability partnership (LLP), partners are typically protected from personal liability for:

options.B: General business debts they personally guarantee
options.C: Negligent acts of other partners and employees they don't supervise

questions.explanation: LLP partners retain personal liability for their own wrongful acts but are generally protected from liability arising from other partners' malpractice or negligence. This is popular for professional service firms.
questions.tip: LLP = protect from others' malpractice, not your own. Compare to LP where limited partners have full protection but can't manage.

questions.question: In bankruptcy, a preference payment that may be recovered by the trustee is a payment made:

options.A: In the ordinary course of business
options.B: Within 90 days before filing, to an existing creditor, for an existing debt, while insolvent
options.D: After the bankruptcy petition is filed

questions.explanation: Preferences are transfers made within 90 days of bankruptcy (1 year for insiders) to existing creditors for existing debts while the debtor was insolvent. They're voidable to ensure equal treatment of creditors.
questions.tip: Preference = unfair payment before bankruptcy. 90 days for regular creditors, 1 year for insiders.

questions.question: A company issues securities under Regulation D Rule 506(b). This exemption allows:

options.B: Sales to unlimited accredited investors and up to 35 sophisticated non-accredited investors
options.C: Sales only within a single state
options.D: Sales only to banks and insurance companies

questions.explanation: Rule 506(b) allows unlimited capital raising from unlimited accredited investors plus up to 35 non-accredited but sophisticated investors. General solicitation is not permitted. It's the most commonly used private placement exemption.
questions.tip: 506(b): No ads, unlimited accredited, 35 sophisticated. 506(c): Ads allowed but accredited only.

questions.question: Under Circular 230, a tax practitioner may charge a contingent fee for:

options.B: Services rendered in connection with an IRS audit
options.C: Amending a return to claim a larger refund

questions.explanation: Circular 230 prohibits contingent fees for preparing original returns, amended returns, and refund claims. Contingent fees are permitted for IRS examinations, appeals, and judicial proceedings.
questions.tip: Contingent fee allowed: Audits, appeals, litigation. NOT allowed: Return prep, amendments, refund claims.

questions.question: A tax preparer who takes an unreasonable position on a return without disclosure may be subject to a penalty of:

options.B: $1,000 or 50% of income derived
options.C: Greater of $1,000 or 50% of income derived

questions.explanation: IRC Section 6694(a) imposes a penalty for unreasonable positions equal to the greater of $1,000 or 50% of income derived from preparing the return. Willful or reckless conduct increases the penalty to the greater of $5,000 or 75%.
questions.tip: Preparer penalty: Unreasonable = greater of $1,000 or 50%. Willful = greater of $5,000 or 75%.

questions.question: A taxpayer in the 32% bracket sells artwork held for 3 years at a $50,000 gain. The gain is taxed at:
questions.explanation: Long-term gains on collectibles (artwork, antiques, coins, stamps, precious metals) are taxed at a maximum rate of 28%, not the normal preferential LTCG rates of 0%/15%/20%.
questions.tip: Collectibles = max 28% LTCG rate. Higher than regular LTCG but lower than ordinary income for high brackets.

questions.question: An activity that lacks a profit motive (hobby) can deduct expenses:

options.B: To the extent of hobby income only
options.C: As an itemized deduction without limitation
options.D: Not at all under current tax law

questions.explanation: Under the TCJA (2018-2025), hobby expenses are not deductible at all because miscellaneous itemized deductions subject to the 2% floor were eliminated. Hobby income is still fully taxable.
questions.tip: Current law (TCJA): Hobby expenses = $0 deduction. Income still taxable. Bad deal for hobbyists.

questions.question: For an instrument to be negotiable, it must contain:

options.A: A signature and any promise to pay
options.B: An unconditional promise or order to pay a fixed amount in money
options.D: The signature of at least two parties

questions.explanation: Negotiability requires: (1) written and signed by maker/drawer, (2) unconditional promise/order, (3) fixed amount of money, (4) payable on demand or at definite time, (5) payable to order or bearer.
questions.tip: Negotiability = WSUFO: Writing, Signed, Unconditional, Fixed money, Order/bearer + demand or definite time.

questions.question: A purchase money security interest (PMSI) in inventory has priority over a conflicting security interest if the PMSI holder:

options.B: Perfects before delivery and notifies prior secured parties
options.D: Registers with the Secretary of State within 30 days

questions.explanation: A PMSI in inventory has super-priority if: (1) perfected when debtor receives possession, and (2) written notice sent to prior secured parties before debtor receives possession. This protects suppliers.
questions.tip: PMSI inventory: Perfect before delivery + notify existing creditors. PMSI non-inventory: Perfect within 20 days.

questions.question: To qualify as a real estate professional and escape passive activity limitations, a taxpayer must:

options.B: Have a real estate license
options.C: Spend more than 750 hours and more than half of personal services in real estate trades or businesses

questions.explanation: Real estate professional status requires: (1) more than 750 hours in real property trades/businesses, AND (2) more than 50% of personal services in real property activities. Material participation in each activity is still required.
questions.tip: RE professional: 750 hours + majority of time in RE. Still need material participation in each rental.

questions.question: The American Opportunity Credit differs from the Lifetime Learning Credit in that it:

options.B: Is partially refundable and limited to first 4 years of college
options.D: Can be claimed by anyone regardless of enrollment status

questions.explanation: The American Opportunity Credit is partially refundable (40%), limited to first 4 years, max $2,500. The Lifetime Learning Credit is non-refundable, available for any year of post-secondary, max $2,000.
questions.tip: AOC: First 4 years, $2,500 max, 40% refundable. LLC: Any year, $2,000 max, non-refundable.

questions.question: A taxpayer who wishes to contest a tax deficiency without first paying the tax must file suit in:

options.B: US Court of Federal Claims

questions.explanation: The US Tax Court allows taxpayers to contest deficiencies before paying. District Court and Court of Federal Claims require full payment first (refund suits). This prepayment forum choice is an important taxpayer right.
questions.tip: Tax Court = contest before paying. District Court/Claims = pay first, sue for refund.
